questions.question: What is the primary use of aperture?
questions.reviewHint: Aperture primarily controls depth of field - how much of the image is in focus.

questions.question: What is the widest aperture?
questions.reviewHint: Wide apertures have smaller f-stop numbers (f/1.4, f/2.8, f/4).

questions.question: How does a wide aperture affect the depth of field?
options: Has no effect on depth of field
questions.reviewHint: Wide apertures create shallow depth of field - less of the image is in focus.

questions.question: Which aperture setting would you use for a landscape photo to get maximum depth of field?
questions.reviewHint: Small apertures (high f-stop numbers) create greater depth of field for landscapes.

questions.question: What happens when you use a small aperture (higher f-stop number)?
options: It takes longer to collect the same quantity of light
It takes less time to collect the same quantity of light
questions.reviewHint: Small apertures have narrow openings, so they collect light more slowly.

questions.question: Which f-stop number represents the smallest aperture opening?
questions.reviewHint: Higher f-stop numbers represent smaller aperture openings.

questions.question: What is the effect of a small aperture on bokeh (background blur)?
options: It makes the background more blurred
It makes the background more defined
It has no effect on the background
questions.reviewHint: Small apertures increase depth of field, making backgrounds more defined.

questions.question: Which of the following would result in the most shallow depth of field?
questions.reviewHint: The widest aperture (smallest f-stop number) creates the shallowest depth of field.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the diaphragm in a camera lens?
questions.reviewHint: The diaphragm is the mechanical component that opens and closes to control the aperture size.

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the circular opening that controls the aperture?
questions.reviewHint: The diaphragm is the mechanical device that creates the aperture opening.

questions.question: If you change the aperture from f/5.6 to f/16, how does this affect exposure time?
questions.reviewHint: Moving to a smaller aperture (higher f-stop) requires longer exposure time to collect the same amount of light.

questions.question: What is the 'sweet spot' of a lens?
options: The widest aperture of the lens
The aperture at which the lens produces the sharpest image
The aperture with the most bokeh
The smallest aperture of the lens
questions.reviewHint: The sweet spot is typically 2-3 stops down from the widest aperture, where the lens performs at its sharpest.

topics.label: Lens sweet spot and optimal sharpness
